questions.text: - Canary, - duke, - opera, - piano, - Prix, - slam.
questions.explanation:
Grand & grand.

	Grand duke, grand opera, grand piano etc. Grand Canary is an island in the Atlantic being part of the Canary Islands.

questions.text: - bag, - cosy, - garden, - leaf, - party, - towel, - trolley
questions.explanation:
Tea & tea.

	Tea bag, tea garden, tea leaf etc. A tea cosy is a covering for a teapot to keep the contents hot. A tea towel is equivalent to a dishtowel in America. A tea trolley is a trolley from which tea is served.

questions.text: - bank, - cell, - donor, - orange, - red, - relation, - sport.
questions.explanation:
Blood & blood.

	Blood bank, blood cell, blood donor etc.

questions.text: - age, - cadet, - capsule, - Invaders, - shuttle, - station
questions.explanation:
Space & space.

	Space age, space capsule, space shuttle etc. A space cadet in American slang is a person who is or appears to be habitually intoxicated through taking drugs. Space Invaders is a video game found in pubs or amusement arcades.

questions.text: - balance, - chicken, - mattress, - onion, - roll, - tide
questions.explanation:
Spring & spring.

	Spring mattress, spring onion (also called green onion or scallion), spring roll etc. Spring balance called a spring scale in USA and a spring chicken called 'springer' in USA and Canada.

Iron & iron.

	Iron Age, Iron Cross, Iron Curtain etc.

General & general.

	General anaesthetic, general Assembly, general election etc.

Nuclear & nuclear.

	Nuclear bomb, nuclear energy, nuclear physics etc.

Steel & steel.

	Steel band, steel grey, steel wool etc. A steel guitar or Hawaiian guitar.

questions.text: - brass, - dog, - drawer, - gear, - hat, - up.
questions.explanation:
Top & top.

	Top brass, top draw, top dog etc. To 'top up' is a British term to raise the level of a liquid or powder.

Test & test.

	Test case, test match, test pilot etc.

Soda & soda.

	Soda lime, soda siphon (soda bottle), soda water (soda) etc. A soda fountain is an American and Canadian term for a counter that serves drinks and snacks.

questions.text: - bar, - cup, - house, - morning, - shop, - table.
questions.explanation:
Coffee & coffee.

	Coffee bar, coffee cup, coffee house etc.

questions.text: - blind, - block, - dance, - King, - lamp, - lounge.
questions.explanation:
Sun & sun.

	Sun blind, sun block, sun dance etc. Louis XIV was known as the 'Sun King'. A sun lounge is known as a sun parlor in the USA.

Real & real.

	Real ale, real estate, real life etc. Real tennis is also called royal tennis.

Paper & paper.

	Paper money, paper tape (perforated tape in the USA). A paper tiger is something that appears powerful but is in fact weak or insignificant. A paper chase is a cross-country run in which a runner lays a trail of paper for others to follow.

Banana & banana.

	Banana skin, banana split etc. Banana oil is a solvent which has a banana-like smell. A banana republic is a small country that is politically unstable and is usually dependent on one export such as bananas.

Beauty & beauty.

	Beauty queen, beauty salon (parlour), beauty sleep etc.

Cape & cape.

	Cape buffalo, Cape Cod, Cape Town etc.

Swiss & swiss.

	Swiss cheese, Swiss Guard, Swiss roll etc.

False & false.

	False alarm, false dawn (zodiacal light appearing just before sunrise), false imprisonment etc.

Human & human.

	Human interest, human nature, human resources etc.

Food & food.

	Food additive, food chain, food poisoning etc.

Wolf & wolf.

	Wolf Cub (the former name for a Cub Scout) wolf whistle, wolf spider (also called hunting spider).

Maiden & maiden.

	Maiden name, maiden over, maiden voyage. 'Maiden over' is a cricket term in which no runs are scored in an over (a set of six balls bowled by a bowler from the same end of the pitch). An 'Australian over' consists of eight balls. Hope you enjoyed the quiz.
